--- title: "Calculus Review" subtitle: "EC 311 - Intermediate Microeconomics" date: last-modified date-format: "YYYY" format: revealjs: theme: [default, styles.scss] slide-number: true footer: "EC311, Lecture 02 | Calculus Overview" preview-links: auto code-fold: FALSE title-slide-attributes: data-background-position: left --- ::: {.vertical-center} [Outline]{.hi .big} - Calculus - Slopes - Derivatives - Multivariate Derivatives ::: # Slopes {.inverse .note} --- name: calculus --- ## Starting Simple ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Main_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: We call the slope the [RISE]{.hi} over [RUN]{.hi} --- ## Functions & Slopes We can write that previous line as a mathematical function: $$f(x) = \dfrac{x}{2} + 5$$ Importantly, the slope for this function is [$1/2$]{.hi} [everywhere]{.hii} . . . - Everywhere means for [all values of $x$]{.hii} - So no matter at what point of the line we calculate the slope, we will always find it to be [$1/2$]{.hi} --- ## Functions & Slopes Slopes can take positive, negative, or zero values And each of these let's us know how the function is behaving as we increse in $x$ (as we move to the right): - Positive values mean the function is increasing - Negative values mean the function is decreasing - Zero values mean the function is staying constant (neither increasing or decreasing) --- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Main_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## Functions & Slopes {.smaller} The previous functions are called linear functions: - Slopes are constant at all values of $x$ - They are behaving in an equal manner at all points . . .
We will mostly be working with non-linear functions, which simply mean they have some form of curvature - We will use quadratic and cubic functions - Quadratic: $f(x) = 3x^{2} + 5x + 10$ - Cubic: $f(x) = x^{3} - 2x^{2} + x - 5$ . . . What we truly care about is their slope. And there is a simpler way to find the slope of a function. # Derivatives {.inverse .note} --- name: derivatives --- ## Definition A [Derivative]{.hii} is simply another function that tells us the slope of a function - It tells us how a function is behaving - A [Derivative]{.hii} will be how we find the slope of our functions . . .
[Mathematically]{.hi} - We will denote a [Derivative]{.hii} as $f'(x)$ - Our original function is labeled $f(x)$ so you can read this as: "The derivative of $f(x)$ is $f'(x)$" - Note that $f'(x)$ is the slope of $f(x)$ at any point $x$ --- ## Intuition ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Main_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960} ::: ::: . . . Initially, the height of the ball is [increasing]{.hi-green} over time Eventually, the height of the ball is [decreasing]{.hi-red} over time --- ## Intuition The sign of the derivative matters a ton! - An [increasing derivative]{.hi-green} means that the function is [going up]{.hi-green} - A [decreasing derivative]{.hi-red} means that the function is [going down]{.hi-red} . . . The [magnitude]{.h} also carries some significance: - A [small absolute value]{.hi} means that the [derivative is moving slowly]{.hi} - A [large absolute value]{.hii} means that the [derivative is moving rapidly]{.hii} . . . > [Note: I am talking about absoltue values so this applies to both positive and negative values. Because we use negatives, our intuition may challenged a bit but hopefully a future example will clear things up]{.h .note} --- ## Derivative Equal to Zero Functions can increase and decrease, which implies something very critical . . . > [Functions can have zero slope!]{.hii} This happens when the function switches from increasing to decreasing (and vice-versa) . . .
[But Why Does This Matter?]{.h} - The switch between positive and negative happens exactly when the function is at its maximum/minimum - And Economics is all about maximizing stuff! - Sometimes we minimize a function but the logic remains the same --- ## Bringing the Math to Economics Think about profits. As a firm, we want to maximize profits so we: :::: {.incremental} - Write down profits as a function of quantity produced - Take its derivative - Set that derivative (remember it is a function) equal to zero - Know how much quantity to produce :::: . . . Once we know what we are doing, the math is extremely simple. The hard part is understanding what we are doing, and then interpreting what a result of $x^{*} = 6$ means. --- ## How Do We Calculate Derivatives? You may already know how to take derivatives but prepare to receive a crash-course in derivative shortcuts . . . Starting with the basics: - $y$ will be a function of $x$ such that $y = f(x)$ - I will be using variables to show general cases so you can look back at how it's done . . . [We will go over the following:]{.hi} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} - Power Rule - Sum (and Difference) Rule - Constant Rule ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} - Log Rule - Chain Rule ::: :::: --- ## Power Rule This will be the most common derivative we will be using $$y = a \cdot x^{b}$$ . . . $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = {\color{red}b} \cdot a \cdot x^{\color{red}{b-1}}$$ . . . For example: $$y = 5x^{3}$$ . . . $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = {\color{red}3} \cdot 5 x^{\color{red}{3-1}} = 15x^{2}$$ --- ## Power Rule (Negative Exponent) Sometimes we will see factors with a negative exponent, like $x^{-3}$ for example As a rule of thumb, you should [always turn your negative exponents into positive ones]{.hii} Thankfully, its a simple process: . . . We just "invert" the negative factor (aka flip the fraction) $$x^{\color{red}-3} = \dfrac{1}{\color{red}{x^{3}}}$$ . . . The derivative works exactly the same way so we can begin with the derivative and then make it positive. --- ## Power Rule (Negative Exponent) So for $y = 5x^{-2}$ we have: $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = -2 \cdot 5x^{-2-1} = -10x^{-3} = \dfrac{-10}{x^{3}}$$ I'll leave it to you to show yourself that making it $y = \dfrac{5}{x^{2}}$ gives the same result --- ## Power Rule (Fractional Exponent) A lot of the time we will have fractional exponents (or decimals) $$y = x^{1/5} = x^{0.2}$$ . . . $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = \dfrac{1}{5} \cdot x^{1/5 - 1} = \dfrac{1}{5} x^{-4/5} = \dfrac{1}{5} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x^{4/5}}$$ . . .
$$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = 0.2 \cdot x^{0.2 - 1} = 0.2 \cdot x^{-0.8} = \dfrac{0.2}{x^{0.8}}$$ --- ## Power Rule (Exponent Equal to 1) Lastly, I'll remind you that every number has a default exponent of 1 That is to say, if we see $3x$ it is equivalent to $3x^{1}$ This helps us take the derivative using the [Power Rule]{.h} For example: $y = -3x$ . . . $$\dfrac{\delta y}{\delta x} = 1 \cdot -3x^{1-1} = -3x^{0} = -3$$ > [The key is to remember that any number with exponent 0 equals 1]{.hi} --- ## Sum (and Difference) Rule Sometimes our functions will have several parts, separated by $\pm$ To make it more general, I'll introduce some new notation: . . . - $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are both functions of $x$. . . . - $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$ refers to the overall derivative of $y$ - This just means that we will take the derivative of all factors that are functions of $x$ \begin{align*} y &= f(x) \pm g(x) \\ \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= f'(x) \pm g'(x) \end{align*} --- ## Sum (and Difference) Rule Let's look at a sum: $$y = x^{2} + 3x$$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} \begin{align*} f(x) &= x^{2} \\ f'(x) &= 2x \end{align*} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} \begin{align*} g(x) &= 3x \\ g'(x) &= 3 \end{align*} ::: :::: . . . $$\dfrac{dy}{dx} = 2x + 3$$ --- ## Sum (and Difference) Rule How about a difference: $$y = x - 3x^{2}$$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} \begin{align*} f(x) &= x \\ f'(x) &= 1 \end{align*} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} \begin{align*} g(x) &= 3x^{2} \\ g'(x) &= 6x \end{align*} ::: :::: . . . $$\dfrac{dy}{dx} = 1 - 6x$$ --- ## Constant Rule Important but straightforward $y = f(x) = a$, where $a$ is a constant ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Main_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960} ::: ::: . . . [$y \;$ does not change as $\; x \;$ increases, so the slope is 0]{.align-center} --- ## Log Rule One of the important functions we will see later uses the natural log function $ln(x)$ ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Main_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960} ::: ::: It's primary use is that it increases at a decreasing rate which is math for it is always going up but by less and less every time --- ## Log Rule $$y = ln(x)$$ . . . $$\dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{x}$$ . . . How about? $$y = a \cdot ln(x)$$ . . . $$\dfrac{dy}{dx} = a \cdot \dfrac{1}{x} = \dfrac{a}{x}$$ --- ## Chain Rule - Sometimes there are multiple operations happening at the same time over a variable. Generelly, it looks like: $$y = f\left(g(x)\right)$$ . . . - We solve this by working from the outside layer to the inner most one, multiplying each time - Learning this is important for derivative math, but we will try to avoid them as much as possible --- ## Chain Rule {.smaller} $$y = \left(x^{3} + 2x\right)^{4}$$ . . . \begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= 4\left( x^{3} + 2x \right)^{4-1} \cdot \left( 3x^{3-1} + 2x^{1-1} \right) \\ &= 4 \left( x^{3} + 2x \right)^{3} \cdot \left( 3x^{2} + 2 \right) \end{align*} . . . How about? $$y = ln(x^{b})$$ . . . \begin{align*} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{1}{x^{b}} \cdot \dfrac{bx^{b-1}}{x^{b}} \\ &= bx^{b-1-b} = bx^{-1} = \dfrac{b}{x} \end{align*} # Multivariate Derivatives {.inverse .note} --- name: multivarite derivatives --- ## Functions with Two Variables For this I need to introduce some new notation - $F = f(x,y)$ is a function of $x$ and $y$ . . . - $F$ now has [2 derivatives]{.h} 1. "With respect to $x$" 2. "With respect to $y$" - Each of these is called a [partial derivative]{.hi} . . . Each [partial derivative]{.hi} is calculated [as if the other variable is a constant number]{.hii} --- ## Multivariate Derivatives Let's try a basic example: $f(x,y) = x + 2y$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - What is the [partial derivative of $x \rightarrow \dfrac{df}{dx}$]{.hi}? - We act as if [$y$ is a constant]{.hii} ::: {.fragment} $$\dfrac{df}{dx} = 1$$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - What is the [partial derivative of $y \rightarrow \dfrac{df}{dx}$]{.hi}? - We act as if [$x$ is a constant]{.hii} ::: {.fragment} $$\dfrac{df}{dy} = 2$$ ::: ::: :::: --- ## Multivariate Derivatives [Additively Separable]{.hi .align-center} $$f(x,y) = ln(x) + 3y$$ :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $x$ :::: {.fragment} $$\dfrac{df}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{x}$$ :::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $y$ :::: {.fragment} $$\dfrac{df}{dy} = 3$$ :::: ::: :::: --- ## Multivariate Derivatives [Non-Separable]{.hi .align-center} $$f(x,y) = x \cdot y$$ :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $x$ :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{df}{dx} &= 1 \cdot x^{1-1} \cdot y \\ &= y \end{align*} :::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $y$ :::: {.fragment} $$\dfrac{df}{dy} = x$$ :::: ::: :::: --- ## Multivariate Derivatives [Non-Separable]{.hi .align-center} $$f(x,y) = x^{2} \cdot y^{1/2}$$ :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $x$ :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{df}{dx} &= 2x^{2-1} \cdot y^{1/2} \\ &= 2xy^{1/2} \end{align*} :::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $y$ :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{df}{dy} &= \dfrac{1}{2}y^{1/2 - 1} \cdot x^{2} \\ &= \dfrac{1}{2} \cdot \dfrac{1}{y^{1/2}} \cdot x^{2} \end{align*} :::: ::: :::: # Optimization {.inverse .note} --- name: optimization --- ## Finding Maximum (or Minimum) Values When we have a continuos function, we can use calculus to find where the largest (or smallest) value will occur - Recall that when the [derivative]{.hii} is [positive]{.h}, then the function is *increasing* - and when the derivative is [negative]{.h}, then the function is *decreasing* . . .
- Where the function is neither increasing nor decreasing, it's either because it's as high as it goes! ## Examples Let's look at an example: $$f(x,y) = 1 - x^2 - y^2 + 2x + 4y$$ How can we figure out where the maximum value of $f()$ will occur? . . . - Let's start by taking some derivatives! . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $x$ :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{df}{dx} &= -2x + 2 \\ \end{align*} :::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $y$ :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{df}{dy} &= -2y + 4 \\ \end{align*} :::: ::: :::: --- ## Examples Let's look at an example: $$f(x,y) = 1 - x^2 - y^2 + 2x + 4y$$ :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $x$ :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{df}{dx} &= -2x + 2 \\ \end{align*} :::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - Partial w.r.t. $y$ :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{df}{dy} &= -2y + 4 \\ \end{align*} :::: ::: :::: --- ## What do these derivatives tell us? - Whether $f()$ is *increasing* or *decreasing* :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - If $x<1$, we know $f()$ is *increasing* with $x$ - If $x>1$, we know $f()$ is *decreasing* with $x$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - If $y<2$, we know $f()$ is *increasing* with $y$ - If $y>2$, we know $f()$ is *decreasing* with $y$ ::: :::: --- ## Examples $$f(x,y) = 1 - x^2 - y^2 + 2x + 4y$$ Let's take an example coordinate and see if it's a *maximum*: starting at the origin: > $(x=0,y=0)$ At $(x=0, y=0)$, $f(0,0) = 1$ - but $\dfrac{df}{dx} = 2$ which tells us we could increase $f()$ by increasing $x$ - also, $\dfrac{df}{dy} = 4$, so we could also increase $f()$ by increasing $y$ . . . So we know $(0,0)$ is not a maximum, and we know which direction to go to look for one --- ## Examples $$f(x,y) = 1 - x^2 - y^2 + 2x + 4y$$ Let's go up in $x$ and $y$: > $(x=1,y=1)$ $f(1,1) = 5$ which is higher, but is it a *maximum*? . . . - $\dfrac{df}{dx} = 0$ - but, $\dfrac{df}{dy} = 2$, so we still could increase $f()$ by increasing $y$ --- ## Examples $$f(x,y) = 1 - x^2 - y^2 + 2x + 4y$$ Let's go up in $x$ and $y$: > $(x=2,y=2)$ $f(2,2) = 5$ which isn't any higher than $(1,1)$ . . . - $\dfrac{df}{dx} = -2$, this tells us we went too far in $x$! - $\dfrac{df}{dy} = 0$, so we should stop increasing $y$ --- ## What *is* the max of this function? Where both partial derivatives are *equal to zero*: - $\dfrac{df}{dx} = 0 \Rightarrow x = 1$ - $\dfrac{df}{dy} = 0 \Rightarrow x = 2$ $f(1,2) = 6$ is the maximum value! --- ## Another Example $$f(x,y) = \sqrt{x^2+y^2}$$ What are the partial derivatives? . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} What is the [partial derivative of $x \rightarrow \dfrac{df}{dx}$]{.hi}? ::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{d}{dx}(x^2+y^2)^\frac{1}{2} & = \\ & \frac{1}{2} (x^2+y^2)^{-\frac{1}{2}} (2x) \\ \dfrac{df}{dx} = 0 & \Rightarrow x = 0 \\ \end{align*} ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} What is the [partial derivative of $y \rightarrow \dfrac{df}{dx}$]{.hi}? ::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} \dfrac{d}{dy}(x^2+y^2)^\frac{1}{2} & = \\ & \frac{1}{2} (x^2+y^2)^{-\frac{1}{2}} (2y) \\ \dfrac{df}{dy} = 0 & \Rightarrow y = 0 \\ \end{align*} ::: ::: :::: ## Calculus Review There is a worksheet on [Canvas](https://canvas.uoregon.edu/courses/236659/files/17824298?module_item_id=4513110) for you to practice everything in this lecture. I recommend you complete it to get the practice in This class is roughly 70% doing math and 30% understanding and interpreting said math

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
